commonExcuses: I need social media for networking

excuseRebuttals: Networking happens in person or via direct communication. If you 'need' social media for networking, you're addicted to scrolling, not networking. Monk Mode reveals truth.
Monk Mode isn't isolation—it's elimination of distractions. You still talk to friends/family directly. You're removing digital noise, not human connection. There's a difference.
One drink restarts dopamine cycle. One peek at social media triggers scroll addiction. Monk Mode is binary: 100% elimination or nothing. No exceptions = transformation.
You have time. Track your day. Most waste 2+ hours on social media, streaming, or scrolling. Monk Mode reallocates that time. You're not adding time—you're eliminating waste.
commonPitfalls: Half-monk (reducing vs eliminating—monk mode requires ZERO, not less)
Social pressure surrender ('just one drink won't hurt'—it breaks the monk contract)
Replacing eliminated dopamine with new vice (food, Netflix, YouTube rabbit holes)
Not filling void with development (elimination without building = empty suffering)
Peeking at social media/porn ('just checking' restarts dopamine cycle completely)
Isolation without purpose (monk mode requires mission: study/build/train)
Breaking during Week 7 New Year's (most critical test—pass this, you're monk forever)
